questions.text: A 65-year-old male smoker with a history of hypertension presents with mild abdominal discomfort and is found to have a pulsatile mass on abdominal examination. His blood pressure is well-controlled on antihypertensive medication. Which of the following is the most common cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atherosclerosis

 

Direct quote from Harrison….’atleast 90% of all abdominal aortic aneurysms >4.0 cm are related to atherosclerotic disease and most are present just below the renal arteries’.

 

Option A:

 

The predominant cause of AAA  is atherosclerosis, a condition characterized by the build-up of fatty deposits, cholesterol, and other substances on the walls of arteries. Over time, this leads to the formation of plaques that can weaken and damage the arterial walls.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While syphilis can cause aortic aneurysms, it is less common in contemporary medicine due to the widespread use of antibiotics. Atherosclerosis is a more prevalent and frequent cause.

 

Option C: Trauma can indeed lead to aortic aneurysms, but it's generally less common than atherosclerosis as a cause. Traumatic aneurysms often result from severe injuries or accidents.

 

Option D: Congenital factors can contribute to the development of aortic aneurysms, but they are less common compared to acquired conditions. Atherosclerosis is still a more prevalent cause in the adult population.

 

Educational objective:

 

The predominant cause of abdominal aortic aneurysm is atherosclerosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 509)

questions.text: Which laboratory test parameter can indicate the highest relative risk for developing atherosclerosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C- reactive protein

 

Option A:

 

C-reactive protein (CRP) is an inflammatory marker that when elevated, indicates endothelial cell activation and is associated with the development of atherosclerosis and cardiovascular risk.

 

  • C- reactive protein (CRP) is an acute phase reactant that causes endothelial cell activation, promote thrombosis and increases leukocyte adhesiveness in developing atheromas.

  • It is an independent predictor of CV risk.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Anti-proteinase 3 (PR3) is an antibody associated with vasculitis, specifically granulomatosis with polyangiitis, and is not a direct marker for atherosclerosis risk.

 

Option C: Cryoglobulins are immunoglobulins that precipitate in the cold and are associated with cryoglobulinemic vasculitis but are not direct indicators of atherosclerotic risk.

 

Option D: Platelet count can reflect thrombotic risk but is not an independent predictor of atherosclerosis or cardiovascular disease like CRP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CRP is an acute-phase reactant that, when elevated, suggests systemic inflammation and is an independent risk factor for atherosclerosis and subsequent cardiovascular events.

questions.text: In 2 patients with atherosclerosis, one is diabetic and the other is non diabetic. In relation to the non diabetic, the diabetic patient has 100 times risk of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lower limb ischemia

Option C: 

The quote from Robbins indicates that diabetic individuals have a risk of lower limb ischemia approximately 100 times higher than that of the general population. Peripheral arterial disease leading to lower limb ischemia is a well-known complication of diabetes due to advanced vascular disease.

  • Direct quote from Robbins... ‘Gangrene of the lower extrem­ities as a result of advanced vascular disease is about 100 times more common in diabetics than in general population’.
  • The risk of myocardial infarction (MI) is twice in a diabetic as compared to a non diabetic individual.

Explanation:

Option A: Diabetic individuals have approximately twice the risk of myocardial infarction (MI) compared to non-diabetics. While diabetes is a significant risk factor for MI, the relative risk is not as high as 100 times compared to the general population.

Option B: Diabetes is a major risk factor for stroke, but the relative risk of stroke in diabetic individuals compared to non-diabetics is not typically cited as 100 times higher. The risk may be elevated, but not to the extent described.

Option D: While diabetes is associated with an increased risk of cerebrovascular disease, including vertebrobasilar insufficiency, the relative risk compared to non-diabetics is not typically stated as 100 times higher.

Educational objective:

Gangrene of the lower extrem­ities as a result of advanced vascular disease is about 100 times more common in diabetics than in general population.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 1145)

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with acute myocardial infarction passed away two days post-admission. Autopsy revealed transmural coagulative necrosis in the myocardium. Which microscopic feature would most likely be present at this stage of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neutrophilic infiltration surrounding coagula­tive necrosis

 

In the early stages of myocardial infarction, coagulative necrosis is typically accompanied by neutrophilic infiltration, indicating the acute inflammatory response to tissue injury. This response occurs before the later stages of healing with features like fibroblasts and collagen deposition.

 

Option C:

 

Neutrophilic infiltration surrounding coagulative necrosis is characteristic of the acute inflammatory response seen in the initial phase of myocardial infarction, which would correspond to the timeline given in the scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Fibroblasts and collagen are typically present during the healing and scar formation phase of myocardial infarction, which generally occurs several days to weeks after the initial event.

 

Option B: Granulation tissue is part of the proliferative phase of healing, usually seen about a week after an MI, not within the first few days.

 

Option D: Granulomatous inflammation is not a feature of myocardial infarction; it is associated with chronic inflammation due to specific diseases such as tuberculosis or sarcoidosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the early stages of myocardial infarction, typically within the first 3 days, neutrophils are the first inflammatory cells to respond to the necrotic tissue, reflecting an acute inflammatory response.

 

Timeline of histological changes after myocardial infarction:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 547)

questions.text: A myocardial infarct showing early granulation tissue has most likely occurred:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Within 1 week

Option C:

Granulation tissue is a part of the healing process after a myocardial infarction (heart attack). It is typically seen within the first week following the infarct. During this phase of healing, inflammatory cells are replaced by granulation tissue, which consists of new blood vessels, fibroblasts, and other connective tissue elements.

Early granulation tissue, which consists of proliferating fibroblasts, new blood vessels (angiogenesis), and the resolution of the acute inflammatory infiltrate, typically appears between 4 and 7 days after an MI as part of the healing process.

Explanation:

Option A: Early granulation tissue does not develop less than 1 hour after an MI. The initial response is one of acute inflammation predominantly involving neutrophils.

Option B: Within 24 hours after an MI, coagulative necrosis begins to occur along with an acute inflammatory response, but granulation tissue is not yet present.

Option D: Within 1 month after an MI, the granulation tissue has usually matured into scar tissue, with dense collagen deposition, rather than early granulation tissue.

Educational Objective:

Early granulation tissue in the context of myocardial infarction typically occurs within 1 week after the event and signifies the replacement of inflammatory cells with new connective tissue elements and blood vessels.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 548)

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with angina on exertion. His cardiovascular risk profile includes hypercholesterolemia and smoking. On histological examination of an arterial biopsy from an atherosclerotic plaque, numerous foam cells are identified. Which of the following components in the patient's blood most likely contributed to the formation of these foam cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oxidised LDL

The process described involves the formation of foam cells in atherosclerotic plaque. Foam cells are derived from macrophages that have engulfed modified low-density lipoproteins (LDL). In the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis, LDL cholesterol undergoes oxidative modifications, turning it into oxidized LDL. Oxidized LDL is more likely to be taken up by macrophages, leading to the formation of foam cells within the atherosclerotic plaque. The accumulation of foam cells contributes to the development and progression of atherosclerosis.

Option C:

oxidized LDL is readily taken up by macrophages through scavenger receptors, leading to foam cell formation, which is a hallmark of atherosclerotic plaque development.

Explanation:

Option A: Lipoproteins are the major carriers of cholesterol in the blood, but not all lipoproteins directly contribute to foam cell formation.

Option B: VLDL is a lipoprotein that primarily carries triglycerides; while it can contribute to plaque formation, it is not the most direct cause of foam cell formation.

Option D: Homocysteine is an amino acid that has been linked to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, but it does not directly lead to foam cell formation.

Educational Objective:

Oxidized LDL is crucial in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis as it is readily engulfed by macrophages to become foam cells, which are a defining feature of atherosclerotic plaques.

 

Robbins 10th 493-5

questions.text: A 45-year-old man has a 2 year history of angina pectoris occurring after exercise. His BP is 136/76 mmHg and is heart rate is 78/min with a 75% narrowing of LAD branch of coronary. Which of the following cells are the initial targets in the pathologic process?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Endothelial cells

Option D:

The initial step in atherosclerosis involves damage to endothelial cells, which triggers a cascade of events leading to the recruitment of inflammatory cells, including monocytes, and the subsequent development of atherosclerotic plaques. In this scenario, a 75% narrowing of the left anterior descending (LAD) coronary artery suggests atherosclerosis, likely initiated by damage to endothelial cells.

Explanation:

Option A: Monocytes are a type of white blood cell that plays a role in the immune system. While they are involved in the later stages of atherosclerosis (the process that leads to the narrowing of blood vessels), they are not the initial targets.

Option B: Smooth muscle cells are a crucial component of blood vessels. In atherosclerosis, they migrate from the tunica media to the intima (the innermost layer of blood vessels), contributing to the formation of atherosclerotic plaques. However, they are not the initial targets in the pathologic process.

Option C: Platelets are small cell fragments involved in blood clotting. In the context of atherosclerosis, they play a crucial role in the initial steps of the process. When there is damage to the endothelial cells lining the blood vessels (the innermost layer), platelets adhere to the exposed collagen, forming a plug and initiating the clotting cascade.

Educational objective:

The initial step in atherosclerosis involves damage to endothelial cells.

questions.text: A 82-year-old man suffering from progressive dementia for the past 10 years dies of bronchopneumonia. At Autopsy, the aortic root and arch is dilated with the intimal surface showing a tree bark appearance. Microscopic examination shows obliterative end arteritis of vasa vasorum of aorta. What laboratory finding is most likely recorded in his medical history.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Antibodies against Treponema pallidum

 

Option C:

 

The described autopsy findings of a dilated aortic root and arch with a tree bark appearance and microscopic evidence of obliterative endarteritis of vasa vasorum are indicative of syphilitic aortitis, which is associated with late-stage syphilis. The laboratory finding most likely recorded in his medical history is option (c) that is Antibodies against Treponema pallidum

 

Options A, B, and D are not typically associated with late-stage syphilis:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: P-ANCA positive 1:1024: This is more indicative of autoimmune vasculitis, not syphilis.

 

Option B: Ketonuria 4+: This finding is suggestive of a metabolic condition, such as diabetic ketoacidosis, and is not directly related to late-stage syphilis.

 

Option D: High ds-DNA titre: Elevated ds-DNA titers are associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), an autoimmune disease, and are not specific to syphilis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilitic aortitis presents as a dilation of the aortic root and arch with a characteristic tree bark appearance of the intima, along with obliterative endarteritis of vasa vasorum in late-stage syphilis. The detection of antibodies against Treponema pallidum in the patient's medical history would confirm the diagnosis of syphilis

choices.text: Necrotic myofibers with presence of neutrophils
Coagulative necrosis of the myocytes with presence of granulation tissue
Infiltration by histiocytes with hemosiderin laden macrophages

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with acute chest pain of 4 hours duration. Electrocardiographic examination revealed new Q wave with ST segment depression. He succumbed to his illness within 24 hours of admission. The heart revealed presence of a transmural hemorrhagic area over the septum and anterior wall of the left ventricle. Light microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Necrotic myofibers with presence of neutro­phils

Option B:

The patient in the question succumbed to myocardial infarction after about 28 hours of the attack. After twenty-four hours of the attack light microscopy shows coagulative necrosis of myofibrils with loss of nuclei and striations along with an interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils.

Within the first 24-72 hours following an MI, coagulative necrosis ensues, characterized by loss of nuclei and striations in myofibers, and a neutrophilic infiltrate as part of the acute inflammatory response.

Explanation:

Option A: While edema can be an early finding, it does not encompass the cellular changes seen in myocardial infarction (MI) 24 hours post-event, which include necrosis and inflammatory cell infiltration, not simply edema among normal myofibers.

Option C: Granulation tissue is part of the healing process that occurs later in the course of myocardial infarction, usually starting to appear approximately one week after the event, not within the first 24 hours.

Option D: Infiltration by histiocytes and the presence of hemosiderin-laden macrophages are typically observed in the later stages of infarct healing, as the macrophages phagocytose the breakdown products of hemorrhage, which is not the case in the acute phase described here.

Educational Objective:

Light microscopic examination of a heart 24 hours post-myocardial infarction would most likely reveal necrotic myofibers with a loss of nuclei and striations, along with an interstitial infiltrate of neutrophils as part of the acute inflammatory response.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 548)

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic complaining of intermittent claudication and a transient episode of slurred speech that resolved within an hour. His medical history is significant for hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. A bruit is auscultated over the carotid arteries bilaterally. Ankle-brachial index testing reveals a reduced ratio of 0.7. The presence of stroke, peripheral vascular disease and atherosclerosis is associated with which hormone?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Insulin deficiency

Option A:

Insulin deficiency leads to diabetes mellitus, which is a significant risk factor for macrovascular complications, including atherosclerosis, peripheral vascular disease, and cerebrovascular accidents, consistent with the patient's symptoms of intermittent claudication and transient ischemic attack (TIA).

Explanation:

Option B: Hyperestrogenemia is not typically associated with macrovascular complications. While estrogen has been found to have a protective effect on the cardiovascular system, excess levels have not been directly linked to the symptoms described in the scenario.

Option C: Hypothyroidism can lead to hyperlipidemia and an increased risk of atherosclerosis, but it is not primarily associated with peripheral vascular disease and stroke as described in this patient's presentation.

Option D: Progesterone is not known to have a direct effect on atherosclerosis, peripheral vascular disease, or stroke risk. It plays various roles in the body, including regulation of the menstrual cycle and maintenance of early pregnancy.

Educational Objective:

Insulin deficiency, which causes diabetes mellitus, is associated with an increased risk of macrovascular complications, such as atherosclerosis, peripheral vascular disease, and stroke, due to the persistent hyperglycemia and its detrimental effects on the vasculature.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 501)

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented with sudden substernal pain, impending doom and died soon after. Autopsy was performed 4 days after his death which showed that, there was a large transmural anterior wall infarction. The histopathological feature would be associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Presence of macrophages

 

As discussed in the video, granulation tissue appears between 7-10 days and collagen appears after 2 months. Between 3-7 days, neutrophils start disintegrating with early phagocytosis caused by macrophages.

 

Option C:

 

Macrophages predominate the myocardial tissue around 3-7 days post-infarction. They are involved in the phagocytosis of dead cells and in the preparation of the tissue for healing, marking the transition from an acute inflammatory response to healing.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Collagen deposition and fibroblast proliferation are characteristic of the later stages of myocardial infarction healing, typically appearing around 2 months after the event when scar tissue is forming.

 

Option B: Neutrophilic infiltration occurs early after myocardial infarction, peaking at around 1-3 days. By day 4, the number of neutrophils starts to decrease as they begin to disintegrate and are phagocytosed by macrophages.

 

Option D: Granulation tissue formation is part of the healing process, but it appears between 7-10 days post-infarction. This tissue is characterized by the proliferation of new capillaries, fibroblasts, and the deposition of extracellular matrix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Between 3-7 days post-myocardial infarction, macrophages are the predominant cell type involved in phagocytosing necrotic cardiac tissue and signify the early stages of the healing process, before the formation of granulation tissue.

 

Histological timeline after MI:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 548)

choices.text: These often result from hypotension or shock

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding subendocar­dial infarction are true, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) These may result in aneurysm

 

Ventricular aneurysms result from transmural infarcts, which involve the whole thickness of myocardium from epicardium to endocardium. Subendocardial infarcts being limited to only the inner one-third or at most one half of the ventricular wall do not cause ventricular aneurysms.

 

Aneurysm of the ventricular wall most commonly re­sults from a large transmural anteroseptal infarct.

 

Option D:

 

This statement is false because ventricular aneurysms typically result from transmural infarcts, which involve the full thickness of the myocardium. Subendocardial infarcts affect only the inner third or at most one-half of the ventricular wall and are not typically associated with the formation of aneurysms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: This is a true statement, can be multifocal because the hypoperfusion affects multiple areas 

 

Option B: Subendocardial MIs often result from conditions that lead to a decreased cardiac output, such as hypotension or shock, leading to a mismatch in oxygen supply and demand.

 

Option C: Epicarditis is not commonly associated with subendocardial MIs because the subendocardial region does not extend to the outer layers of the heart wall where the epicardium is located.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subendocardial myocardial infarctions, affecting only the inner layers of the myocardial wall, do not generally lead to the formation of ventricular aneurysms, which are more commonly associated with transmural myocardial infarctions involving the full thickness of the myocardial wall.

 

Subendocardial infarction – detailed explanation:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 548)

choices.text: Omega-3 fatty acid (abundant in fish oil) decrease triglycerides
Atherosclerosis is less important in age more than 45 years age
Cigarette smoking is independent risk factor for M.I
C reactive protein is independent risk factor for M.I

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding atherosclerosis are true except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atherosclerosis is less important in age more than 45 years age

 

Option B:

 

Atherosclerosis is not less important in individuals over 45 years of age; in fact, aging is a significant risk factor for the development and progression of atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is a complex, progressive disease that involves the accumulation of plaque within the arteries, leading to vessel narrowing and impaired blood flow. Aging contributes to the structural and functional changes in blood vessels, making them more prone to atherosclerosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Omega-3 fatty acids have been shown to have various cardiovascular benefits; including reducing levels of triglycerides cholesterol.

 

Option C: Cigarette smoking is a well-established independent risk factor for myocardial infarction (M.I) and other cardiovascular diseases. Smoking contributes to atherosclerosis, increases blood clotting, and has detrimental effects on blood vessels.

 

Option D: Elevated levels of C-reactive protein (CRP), a marker of inflammation, have been associated with an increased risk of myocardial infarction and other cardiovascular events. It is considered an independent risk factor.

 

Educational objective:

 

Atherosclerosis is more important in age more than 45 years age as aging is a significant risk factor for the development and progression of atherosclerosis.

 

  • Age is one of the most powerful non-modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis.
  • Atherosclerosis is:
    • Rare and less significant in young adults (<30).
    • Becomes more important clinically after age 45–50, when it starts to manifest as angina, MI, stroke, peripheral artery disease.
  • So, as age increases:
    • The prevalence, extent, and severity of atherosclerotic plaques increase.
    • The clinical consequences become more common and significant.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 495)
